To make reverse engineering more difficult, the main payload of Emotet usually applies an obfuscation technique called Control-flow flattening. This technique is used to break the flow of a program's execution by flattening it. When the control flow is flattened, the program is divided into blocks, all of which are at the same level. Therefore, it will be difficult to determine the execution order of the program at first glance. ### 5.2

To make reverse engineering more difficult, the main payload of Emotet usually consists of two parts: - An executable file named `emotex` which contains code from the original sample; - Another binary called `exe_file`, containing only legitimate Windows executables such as `cmd.exe`. This second part can also contain other files like `msiexec.exe`; however, these additional files should not have any functionality beyond loading the first stage binary into memory.

SiestaGraph achieved persistence across system updates by infecting the master boot record (MBR) of affected systems. It also created a bootkit that would reinstall the malware if it was removed, ensuring persistence even after major system updates or reimaging attempts. The malware achieved persistence across system updates through two main methods: 1) It infected the master boot record (MBR) of affected systems. 2) It created a bootkit that would reinstall the malware if it was removed

The SiestaGraph application has been installed on all systems as part of normal software update processes. It then checks if any new versions have been released since its last installation date. If so, it will install them automatically without user interaction. This process can take up to several hours depending on how many users there are. Afterwards, the program runs itself every day at midnight UTC.

TRITON implements the TriStation protocol, which is the protocol used by the legitimate TriStation application, to configure controllers. TsHi is the high-level interface created by the malware's authors that allows the threat actor's operators to implement attack scripts using the TRITON framework. It exposes functions for both reconnaissance and attack. The functions generally accept binary

The TRITON implant uses the "TriStatute Protocol", also called TCP/IPv6 Router Advertisement Protocol (RAP). This protocol allows devices on different subnets to communicate directly without having to use NAT. It can be configured as either a stateless or stateful implementation. In both cases, each device sends its own unique ID when sending packets through the network. When receiving data from another device, the router will check if there has been any change since last time they received such information. If so, then it will send back a new packet containing all changes made between them.

A tunnel between two firewalls on different subnets can only exist if they have been configured as separate virtual machines. This would allow them to communicate through NAT without being able to see one another directly. In reality, however, these devices will likely share some common hardware resources such as CPU cores, memory, storage, etc. Therefore, we need to create fake network connections so that both systems appear to be connected when actually not. To do this, we use a technique called "virtualization." Virtualization allows us to simulate multiple physical servers inside our simulator environment while still maintaining their unique identities.

A new threat actor has been identified as "Team B". They have continued their operations against organizations worldwide since at least June 2022. Their primary focus remains targeting government entities and critical infrastructures. This group uses multiple tactics including spear phishing emails containing links to compromised websites hosting malicious documents. These files contain macros which execute code from remote servers. In addition, they use social engineering lure campaigns such as email spoofings designed to trick recipients into opening malicious attachments.

A phishing email from "the group." It contained links to two documents which were downloaded as attachments. One document contains information about how to download another file called `trojan_downloader` from a server hosted on `hxxps://www[.]google.[.]com/`. This link leads to a page containing JavaScript code that loads a second HTML file named `install.html`, which then executes a PowerShell script that drops a DLL into `%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\startup\msiexec.exe`.
Enabling the macros of the Excel file downloads a file created using NSIS installer with ServHelper from 79[.]141[.]168[.]105 or 195[.]123[.]213[.]126

The macro code creates a new folder named "C:\Users\Public". It then copies itself into the newly created folder. This copy contains two files - one containing the original Excel document and another which has been renamed as 'Macro_Viewer'. When opened, Macro Viewer displays the contents of the Excel document.

A SFX archive containing a .NET executable file named "Invisible". This sample uses legitimate Microsoft Office tools such as Word and Excel to create a fake document which contains code obfuscated with XOR encryption. ServHelper has commands for adding a remote desktop user and sending RDP traffic to the attacker through a reverse SSH tunnel

A ServHelper service on Windows Server 2016 hosts multiple services including Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). It can also run PowerShell scripts as well as other programs such as Microsoft Office applications. This script will send outbound RDP packets from any machine connected to the local network.

To cover their tracks the attackers used secure deletion tools to wipe logs and other artifacts from compromised systems. They also used timestomping to alter file metadata and confuse forensic timeline analysis. In some cases they deployed anti-forensic tools that overwrote free space on drives to make data recovery more difficult. The attackers used several techniques to cover their tracks and eliminate forensic evidence: 1) Secure deletion tools to wipe logs and other artifacts from compromised systems
The attacker deleted files from disk using Secure Delete Tools on Windows systems. This technique can also be leveraged against Linux hosts as well.
